entry.title: DMN editor opens 1.1 and 1.3 assets now

link.title: DMN editor opens 1.1 and 1.3 assets now

entry.content:
The DMN editor continues evolving towards making users‚Äô lives as simple as possible. On Kogito 0.8.1, we introduce a new mechanism to open DMN 1.1 and 1.3 assets.

We‚Äôre still saving your model as a DMN 1.2 asset at conformance level 3. However, now any 1.1 or 1.3 model, non including DMN 1.3 features, is converted to 1.2.

In other words, you can now open DMN 1.1, 1.2, and 1.3 models in the editor, as you can see :-)

As you probably have already noticed, this is a baby step toward fully-supporting the DMN 1.3 spec, but it‚Äôs already great news. If you‚Äôre using an older version of the editor, or even if you have DMN models from other vendors persisted as DMN 1.1 or 1.3, you‚Äôre now able to open them on VSCode, Online Editor, and on any other Kogito channel.

Thinking on the tooling‚Äôs future, we‚Äôve also introduced a backward compatibility test suite with almost every file pushed in the dmn-tck repository. It ensures that new Kogito releases will continue supporting older DMN versions without any regression.

We‚Äôll release Kogito 0.8.1 in a few days with other surprising news. Stay tuned! ;-)
entry.summary: The DMN editor continues evolving towards making users‚Äô lives as simple as possible. On Kogito 0.8.1, we introduce a new mechanism to open DMN 1.1 and 1.3 assets.

entry.title: DMN lives in the KIE Group YouTube channel

link.title: DMN lives in the KIE Group YouTube channel

entry.content:
The KIE YouTube channel is regularly posting quite interesting content!

Last week I had the pleasure of presenting a talk about DMN at the KieLive#11 session:

Tomorrow (October 27th), Edson Tirelli will also talk about DMN, but from a different and more advanced perspective at the KieLive#12:

I‚Äôve just activated the YouTube reminder because I won‚Äôt miss it.

Joy there as well :-)
entry.summary: The KIE YouTube channel is regularly posting quite interesting content!

entry.title: How to maintain DMN models on Business Central and VSCode

link.title: How to maintain DMN models on Business Central and VSCode

entry.content:
Currently, the DMN editor is supported in a variety of environments. You can create a DMN model in an online editor, in a chrome extension, in a desktop app, in a VSCode extension, and even on Business Central.

Until the latest release, you could face some differences between a model created by VSCode and a one created by Business Central. Now, this post aims to demonstrate that both environments are fully compatible by showing the same project from two perspectives: I) how to create a project on VSCode and import it on Business Central, and II) how to create a project on Business Central and import it on VSCode.

Let‚Äôs check both environments.

‚Äì

The VSCode perspective

Let‚Äôs get started to understand how to use VSCode to handle a DMN file in a context of a Business Central project by relying only on VSCode.

  • In a shell prompt, enter the following mvn command to create a project:
mvn archetype:generate \
  -DarchetypeGroupId=org.kie \
  -DarchetypeArtifactId=kie-kjar-archetype \
  -DarchetypeVersion=7.44.0.Final \
  -DartifactId="Some Application" \
  -DgroupId="org.kie" \
  -DartifactId="vscode-2-bc"

  • When the archetype plug-in switches to interactive mode, accept the default values for the remaining fields

  • After generating your project, create a DMN asset at the src/main/resources/<your package> directory and populate it with some interesting decision, like the one in the video:

  • Now, initialize the git repository for your project, add all files, and commit them:
git init && git add . && git commit -m "Init"

  • Use pwd to get the local path of your project

  • Open the Business Central spaces screen, click on Import Project, and set file://<the local path of your project> as the Repository URL

  • Done! You‚Äôve successfully created a Business Central project relying only on your terminal and on your VSCode DMN editor! üéâ

‚Äì

The Business Central perspective

Alright, now let‚Äôs do the opposite. Let‚Äôs create a project on Business Central and import it to VSCode.

  • Create a project on Business Central in the spaces screen

  • Create a DMN asset and populate it with some interesting decision, like the one in the video above

  • Now, click on ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù to open the project settings screen

  • Copy the HTTP URL of your project

  • Clone the URL of your project
git clone http://localhost:8080/business-central/git/MySpace/bc-2-vscode

  • Open the project directory with VSCode

  • Done! You‚Äôve successfully opened your Business Central project with VSCode. You can now perform changes into your DMN mode, commit them with git, and the Business Central will automatically detect them

‚Äì

I hope you‚Äôve enjoyed this quick tutorial! Stay tuned for new DMN features! :-)
entry.summary: Currently, the DMN editor is supported in a variety of environments. You can create a DMN model in an online editor, in a chrome extension, in a desktop app, in a VSCode extension, and even on Business Central.

entry.title: DMN editor supports multiple diagrams now

link.title: DMN editor supports multiple diagrams now

entry.content:
The DMN editor was already great for expressing business logic and decomposing complex decisions into multiple nodes.

However, in some advanced use cases, your graph may get complicated, and your model might look like this:

I‚Äôve removed all labels from this example to focus on the number of nodes and their relationship. Even without acknowledging the decision logic that some elements hold, we easily notice that two subsets compose the decision logic.

This kind of scenario frequently happens on large DMN models since they generally have a tree layout. Now, when you meet a situation like that one, you‚Äôre able to decompose the model logic into subsets.

Creating Decision Requirements Diagrams (DRD) for each subset is relatively straightforward. For composing a new DRD from many nodes, select them and right-click. Also, you can create a diagram from a single node by clicking on the DRD icon:

Dividing a problem into smaller and simpler pieces is always an excellent idea, and now we have another approach for that.

We already could decompose a huge business decisions into multiple meaningful nodes. We also could split a DMN model toward various models and reuse their logic by relying on the Included Models tab.

Now, we can finally break the DMN graph into many sub-digrams. It‚Äôs all about simplifying how we visually express decisions.

Stay tuned for the future updates! ;-)

-

Notice: in some use cases, when your DMN model contains multiple decision requirements diagrams (DRDs), you may face some validation errors that prevent the execution. You can the kogito.decisions.validation=DISABLED property into the application.properties to disable model validation and successfully execute the model. This is issue wont be present on Kogito Tooling 0.7.1 (end of October) - KOGITO-3571.
entry.summary: The DMN editor was already great for expressing business logic and decomposing complex decisions into multiple nodes.

entry.title: [URLOTW] Bevy Engine
entry.content:
URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)

This week the winner is Bevy Engine: bevyengine.org.

Rust ecosystem is still young, but it has enough libraries and game engines to provide you en experimental game development environment (you may check more details about the Rust game development community here).

Bevy is a quite simple data-driven game engine written in Rust. If you want to try it, I recommend you to check this list of Bevy-based-projects. You may find some inspiration there to start your own! :-)
entry.summary: URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)

entry.title: [URLOTW] Build Superhuman Reinforcement Learning
entry.content:
URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)

This week the winner is Build Superhuman Reinforcement Learning in 10 Minutes: ericvanular.com/build-superhuman-RL-in-10-min.

It‚Äôs cool how good results we can achieve with a naive but well-polished reinforcement learning implementation. The article above summarizes a nice and very quick example :-)

I hope you enjoy it!
entry.summary: URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)

entry.title: [URLOTW] Ten modern layouts in one line of CSS

link.title: [URLOTW] Ten modern layouts in one line of CSS

entry.content:
URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)

This week the winner is Ten modern layouts in one line of CSS: web.dev/one-line-layouts.

This is one of the best CSS posts I have ever see. It‚Äôs a must-read if you write at least one line of CSS code per month ;-)

It‚Äôs a really rewarding reading. I hope you enjoy it!

entry.title: Boosting video fps using AI
entry.content:
These days I was spending some time on YouTube when I faced this incredible video, and I really want to share it with you:

When I finished it, I was already stunned, but then I found these other even more impressive videos: sites.google.com/view/wenbobao/dain. It engaged me in understanding how that works.

If you‚Äôve got curious like me, you can check the project‚Äôs source code here.

I‚Äôve not finished reading the paper yet, but it is quite interesting to understand the mechanism behind this kind of project.

I hope you like it as well! :-)
entry.summary: These days I was spending some time on YouTube when I faced this incredible video, and I really want to share it with you:

entry.title: The DMN-cli is finally available
entry.content:
Have you ever needed to handle a batch of DMN files? Or even.. have you tried to list nodes of some model by using the command-line?

Feeling this pain, I‚Äôve created the DMN-cli as a starting point for simple command-line operations on DMN files.

The DMN-cli is a tool that allows you to manage, inspect, and preview DMN models easily. You can check the repository here. Contributions and suggestions are more than welcome :-)
entry.summary: Have you ever needed to handle a batch of DMN files? Or even.. have you tried to list nodes of some model by using the command-line?

entry.title: [URLOTW] Rust sokoban
entry.content:
URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)

This week the winner is Rust sokoban: sokoban.iolivia.me/c01-00-intro.html.

I‚Äôm having so much fun learning Rust that I‚Äôm trying to implement different kinds of challenges to continue getting familiar with the language.

Rust Sokoban is an entertaining tutorial that teaches you how to make a Sokoban copy in Rust. I hope you have a good time implementing it or even reading it ;-)
entry.summary: URLOTW or URL of the week or Uniform Resource Locator of the week is a kind of post where I share a relevant URL for you :-)
